docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when the governor of Missouri has ordered every third light bulb unscrewed to save money, when teachers are doubling as janitors in Oklahoma and working two weeks without pay in Oregon, when Connecticut is laying off prosecutors and Kentucky is releasing prison inmates early, the veterinarian crisis in Nebraska may seem like small potatoes. Nebraska has dismissed two of its three state diagnostic veterinarians, meaning a rancher with a sick cow in Scottsbluff now has to drive the length of the state to see what's up with Nellie.

headline.main: States, Facing Budget Shortfalls, Cut the Major and the Mundane

docs.abstract: States are facing severe financial crises, and cutting everything they possibly can to deal with budget shortfalls; two largest areas of state spending, education and Medicaid, are taking brunt of cuts; states were flush in 1990's, and most chose to slash taxes while increasing spending on popular programs; now tax receipts are falling and rainy day reserve funds have been depleted; at depth of their desperation, even some states with strong no-new-tax traditions are raising taxes; program cuts in various states discussed; maps show 2003 fiscal year budget shortfalls state by state; photos (M)
docs.snippet: At a time when the governor of Missouri has ordered every third light bulb unscrewed to save money, when teachers are doubling as janitors in Oklahoma and working two weeks without pay in Oregon, when Connecticut is laying off prosecutors and...

docs.lead_paragraph: After a 12-week trial and 8 days of deliberations, a federal judge declared a mistrial last week in the case of the Nassau County employees' health insurance scandal that prosecutors claimed cost taxpayers $70 million. Judge Joanna Seybert of Federal District Court declared the mistrial after jurors sent her a note saying they were hopelessly deadlocked on the charges.

headline.main: Judge Declares Mistrial In Insurance Case

docs.abstract: Federal District Judge Joanna Seybert, with jurors deadlocked, declares mistrial in Nassau County employees' health insurance scandal involving Albert Isernio, former chief executive officer of Benefit Plan Administrators in Melville, NY; retrial is scheduled for September (M)
docs.snippet: After a 12-week trial and 8 days of deliberations, a federal judge declared a mistrial last week in the case of the Nassau County employees' health insurance scandal that prosecutors claimed cost taxpayers $70 million.    Judge Joanna Seybert of...

docs.lead_paragraph: ALMOST half the state's superintendents and educators are trying to figure where they went wrong. When they finish sorting that out, they will have to resubmit their school budgets to municipal boards and councils and decide where they can cut -- from personnel or programs. On Tuesday, voters in 208 of the state's 550 school districts, or 63 percent of them, rejected their budgets, and 342 approved them. In all, the New Jersey School Boards Association said that only 14.7 percent of all registered voters went to the polls last week -- a typically meager turnout.

headline.main: A Mixed Message For the Schools

docs.abstract: Voters in 208 of New Jersey's 505 school districts reject proposed budgets and 343 approve them; results around state are mixed, with 80 percent of proposed budgets in Essex, Morris, Mercer and Middlesex counties approved compared with less than 50 percent in Hunterdon, Passaic, Camden, Burlington and Salem counties; district superintendents express dismay at low voter turnout; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ALMOST half the state's superintendents and educators are trying to figure where they went wrong. When they finish sorting that out, they will have to resubmit their school budgets to municipal boards and councils and decide where they can cut --...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tuition may be rising at two-year community colleges in Nassau and Suffolk because of cuts in Gov. Pataki's proposed budget. The trustees of Suffolk County Community College have approved a $400 increase for full-time students to take effect for the fall semester. The increase, which is in the proposed $128.8 million proposed college budget submitted to Suffolk County earlier this month, would raise tuition nearly 17 percent, to $2,800.
docs.abstract: Suffolk County Community College trustees, citing proposed state budget cuts, approve $400 tuition increase for full-time students, effective in fall; Nassau County Community College administrators reportedly recommend $275 hike in tuition; officials at both colleges say increases could be lowered if state aid is restored or counties increase their share (M)
docs.snippet: Tuition may be rising at two-year community colleges in Nassau and Suffolk because of cuts in Gov. Pataki's proposed budget.    The trustees of Suffolk County Community College have approved a $400 increase for full-time students to take effect for...

docs.lead_paragraph: AS someone whose job is to keep her finger on the pulse of New York's economy, Trudy Steinfeld, director of career services at New York University, is hard pressed to think of a worse time for the city's job scene. Nonetheless, she tells the thousands of students who graduate from N.Y.U. each year that it is not hard to land a job so long as they take a shrewd approach to their job search. ''Is the job market one of the worst in the 20 years I've been in this business?'' Ms. Steinfeld said. ''Yes. The reason is so many different sectors have been hit at once, especially financial services and information technology. Those two fields have had a lot of jobs evaporate because of market conditions.''
docs.abstract: Trudy Steinfeld, director of career services at New York University, tells thousands of students who graduate from NYU each year that it is not hard to land a job so long as they take shrewd approach to the job search; says this, even as she acknowledges job market is one of worst in 20 years she has been in her job; photo; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FEELING anxious or depressed? The continuing uncertainties of war, terrorism and the weak economy have left many people longing for stability and looking for ways to cope. But just when some people could arguably gain the most by spending a little time on a therapist's couch, their mental health benefits are at risk. In a survey this month by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press in Washington, about a third of the people questioned said they felt depressed by the war with Iraq. Russ Newman, executive director for professional practice at the American Psychological Association, said the war was affecting the vast majority of the group's patients, based on a survey conducted last month, but that it was ''just the latest stressor.''

headline.main: Stress Is Up. So Why Are Mental Health Benefits Down?

docs.abstract: Michelle Andrews column on moves by employers to end or cut mental health benefits at time of increasing stress; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: From the foot of the Delaware Memorial Bridge, where the cars spill in from New Jersey, it is an easy 1.9-mile swoop (three minutes in good traffic) to the Delaware Tobacco Outlet. On Saturday, the manager, Shirley Legeza, arrived to find a busload of New Yorkers waiting for her to open. Not a mile down Route 13, past the gun store, Ellie Taylor surveyed the parking lot this morning at her shop, Airport News and Tobacco: ''Six cars, all New Jersey.''

headline.main: New Castle Journal; Where Cigarette Sales Have Increased Tenfold

docs.abstract: Cigarette smokers in New Jersey are driving across state line to New Castle, Del: Delaware tax is 24 cents a pack, compared with New Jersey's $1.50 a pack; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of workers filing claims for unemployment benefits increased last week to the second-highest level of the year as struggling companies handed out more pink slips. The Labor Department reported today that new applications for jobless benefits rose by a seasonally adjusted 30,000, to 442,000, for the workweek ended April 12.

headline.main: Jobless Figure Is Approaching High for Year

docs.abstract: Labor Department reports new applications for jobless benefits rose by seasonally adjusted 30,000, to 442,000, for workweek ended April 12; increase pushes claims to their highest point since March 29, when claims hit 443,000, highest level of year; graph (M)3
docs.snippet: The number of workers filing claims for unemployment benefits increased last week to the second-highest level of the year as struggling companies handed out more pink slips.    The Labor Department reported today that new applications for jobless...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the largest Medicaid fraud settlement, Bayer agreed yesterday to pay the government $257 million and pleaded guilty to a criminal charge after engaging in what federal prosecutors said was a scheme to overcharge for the antibiotic Cipro. According to documents turned over to the government by a whistle-blower, Bayer was coached in the scheme by a purchasing manager from Kaiser Permanente, one of the nation's largest health care organizations.

headline.main: Bayer Agrees To Pay U.S. $257 Million In Drug Fraud

docs.abstract: Bayer AG, in largest Medicaid fraud settlement, agrees to pay government $257 million and pleads guilty to criminal charge after engaging in what federal prosecutors say was scheme to overcharge for antibiotic Cipro; fraud involved selling Cipro to health care organization Kaiser Permanente at prices lower than company was charging Medicaid, in violation of federal law that requires drug makers to give Medicaid .rogram lowest price charged to any customer; Cipro bottles sold to Kaiser were relabeled with Kaiser's name and given different drug identification number to cover up fraud; Kaiser is not charged with any wrongdoing; prosecutors also announce that GlaxoSmithKline agrees to pay $87.6 million to settle civil charges that it overcharged Medicaid program for antidepressant Paxil and allergy spray Flonase; deal also involves relabeling medicines for Kaiser; money from settlements will be divided by federal and state governments, which jointly pay for Medicaid; portion will go to public health clinics, AIDS programs, and other groups that are allowed to buy medicines at Medicaid price; about $34 million of Bayer settlement will go to estate of late George J Couto, former Bayer executive who became whistle-blower; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In the largest Medicaid fraud settlement, Bayer agreed yesterday to pay the government $257 million and pleaded guilty to a criminal charge after engaging in what federal prosecutors said was a scheme to overcharge for the antibiotic Cipro.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: A banner slogan on the Web site of the company founded by C. Sage Givens reads, ''Connecting with the right people makes all the difference.'' For better and for worse, the crucial connection for Ms. Givens has been to Richard M. Scrushy, the founder and former chairman of HealthSouth now accused by securities regulators of inflating earnings from virtually the time the company went public in 1985.

headline.main: Questions About Investor On Board of HealthSouth

docs.abstract: C Sage Givens, venture capitalist who is member of HealthSouth Corp's board and serves on its audit committee, has ties to company; number of corporate governance experts suggest that Givens's web of financial ties to companies affiliated with HealthSouth may have prevented her from being truly objective and independent director; her continuing role highlights conflicts that often develop when venture capital investors serve on corporate boards; several bankers with close ties to HealthSouth board say Givens successfully challenged founder and former chairman Richard M Scrushy on numerous occasions about his pay packages; photo (M)
